content: Callie Steffen is a graudate student at the Bren School of Environmental Science and Management. Her research interests include environmental and human impacts on marine mammal populations.
summary: Callie Steffen is a graudate student at the Bren School of Environmental Science and Management. Her research interests include environmental and human impacts on marine mammal populations.
title: Callie Steffen

content:
Introduction: This analysis will explore land use and watersheds for the big island of Hawaii. The land use and land cover data was primarily based on the interpretation of aerial photography from the 1970’s and 1980’s, with secondary sources including land use maps and surveys. Watersheds are shown for the 8 major islands and measured in square miles.
See metadata (linked below) for specific watershed names and more detailed descriptions of what is included in the 7 categories of land cover.
Land use Data Source: Land Use Land Cover of main Hawaiian Islands as of 1976 Source: 1:100,000 1976 Digital GIRAS (Geographic Information Retrieval and Analysis) files. http://geoportal.hawaii.gov/datasets/land-use-land-cover-lulc
Watershed Data Source: State of Hawaii Commission on Water Resource Management (CWRM), 2008. http://geoportal.hawaii.gov/datasets/watersheds
Shoreline Imagery of Hawaiian Islands. Photo Source: University of Hawaii MANOA, Coastal Geology Group
  Data Analysis and Cleaning plot(watershed) plot(landuse) st_crs(landuse) #4326 st_crs(watershed) #4326 # recategorize landcover column data into categories based off of the metadata so we have fewer categories to visualize making for a cleaner map landuse_metadata <- landuse %>% mutate( landcover_md = case_when( landcover %in% c("Residential", "Commercial and Services", "Industrial", "Transportation, Communications and Utilities", "Industrial and Commercial Complexes", "Mixed Urban or Built-up Land", "Other Urban or Built-up Land") ~"Urban or Built-up Land", landcover %in% c("Cropland and Pasture", "Orchards, Groves, Vineyards, Nurseries and Ornamental Horticultural Areas", "Confined Feeding Operations","Other Agricultural Land") ~ "Agricultural Land", landcover %in% c("Herbaceous Rangeland", "Shrub and Brush Rangeland", "Mixed Rangeland") ~ "Rangeland", landcover %in% c("Deciduous Forest Land", "Evergreen Forest Land", "Mixed Forest Land") ~ "Forest Land", landcover %in% c("Streams and Canals", "Lakes", "Reservoirs", "Bays and Estuaries") ~ "Water", landcover %in% c("Dry Salt Flats", "Beaches", "Sandy Areas Other than Beaches", "Bare Exposed Rock", "Strip Mines, Quarries and Gravel Pits", "Transitional Areas", "Mixed Barren Land") ~ "Barren Land" , landcover %in% c("Shrub and Brush Tundra", "Herbaceous Tundra", "Bare Ground", "Wet Tundra", "Mixed Tundra") ~ "Tundra" , landcover %in% c("Perrenial Snowfield", "Glaciers") ~ "Perrenial Snow", landcover %in% c("Forested Wetland", "Nonforested Wetland") ~ "Wetland"))  Map of Land Cover Categories for all 8 islands (Hawaii) # Plot for Land Use on all of hawaiian islands landcover_gg <- ggplot(data = landuse_metadata) + geom_sf(data = landuse_metadata,color = "NA", aes(fill = landcover_md)) + xlab("Longitude") + ylab("Latitude") + annotation_scale(location = "bl", width_hint = 0.5) + annotation_north_arrow(location = "bl", which_north = "true", pad_x = unit(0.75, "in"), pad_y = unit(0.5, "in"), style = north_arrow_fancy_orienteering) + coord_sf(crs = st_crs(4326)) + labs(fill='Land Cover Category') + scale_fill_discrete(na.translate=F) landcover_gg  Figure 1: Figure 1. Land Cover categories for all 8 islands in Hawaii. Data was recategorized into 7 main categories.   Map of Watersheds for all 8 islands (Hawaii) #plot for watersheds on all of hawaiian islands ggplot(data = watershed) + geom_sf(data = watershed,color = "NA", aes(fill = area_sqmi)) + xlab("Longitude") + ylab("Latitude") + annotation_scale(location = "bl", width_hint = 0.5) + annotation_north_arrow(location = "bl", which_north = "true", pad_x = unit(0.75, "in"), pad_y = unit(0.5, "in"), style = north_arrow_fancy_orienteering) + coord_sf(crs = st_crs(4326)) + labs(fill='Area of Watershed (sqmi)')  Figure 2: Figure 2. Watersheds of the 8 islands of Hawaii. There are 558 watersheds between the 8 islands and they are measured in square miles and each has an individual name.
summary:
Introduction: This analysis will explore land use and watersheds for the big island of Hawaii. The land use and land cover data was primarily based on the interpretation of aerial photography from the 1970’s and 1980’s, with secondary sources including land use maps and surveys. Watersheds are shown for the 8 major islands and measured in square miles.
See metadata (linked below) for specific watershed names and more detailed descriptions of what is included in the 7 categories of land cover.
title: Hawaiian Islands: Landcover and Watersheds

content:
Introduction: PCA of USDA Food Group: Eggs and Dairy Products This Principle Component Analysis (PCA) explores relationships of nutrient variables of Dairy and Egg Products based off data from the United States Department of Agriculture. By performing a PCA, we can simplify the dimensions of the data while still explaining a majority of the variance
Data source: U.S. Department of Agriculture, Agricultural Research Service. 2018. USDA Food and Nutrient Database for Dietary Studies 2015-2016. Food Surveys Research Group Home Page, http://www.ars.usda.gov/nea/bhnrc/fsrg
Dairy Products. Photo Source: USDA
  Data Cleaning for Analysis #Interested in exploring the food group of dairy and eggs, so will filter data for that food group and differnt nutrient aspects dairy_df <- usda %>% clean_names() %>% filter(food_group == c("Dairy and Egg Products")) %>% select(food_group,protein_g,sugar_g,fat_g,carb_g,energy_kcal,fiber_g) #Exploring any NAs summary(dairy_df) skim(dairy_df) gg_miss_var(dairy_df) # No missing values  Analysis: Running PCA on Dairy Data #pca dairy_pca <- prcomp(dairy_df[2:7], scale = TRUE) dairy_pca summary(dairy_pca) ##my frist two PC explain ~69% of data plot(dairy_pca) #shows variance biplot(dairy_pca) #looks messy Between Principle Component 1 and Principle Component 2, ~69% of variance is captured. This simplifies the the number of dimensions, and by only using 2 of the 6 Principle Components (axes) we are still able to explain over half of the variance of the data.
 Visualizing Biplot of PCA #Visualize with ggfortify for a cleaner graph dairy_biplot <- autoplot(dairy_pca, colour = NA, loadings.label = TRUE, loadings.label.size = 4, loadings.label.colour = "black", loadings.label.repel = TRUE) + theme(axis.title = element_text(face="bold")) + theme_minimal() dairy_biplot   Figure 1: Figure 1.Principle Component Analysis of Nutrient Information on Egg and Dairy Products to Explore Relationship Between Nutrient Variables.  Angles between the vectors will tell you how much each characteristics correlate with each other.
 Protein and Fat are positively correlated Sugar and carbs are highly positively correlated There is almost no correlation between sugar and energy_kcal Fiber and fat are negatively correlated
summary:
Introduction: PCA of USDA Food Group: Eggs and Dairy Products This Principle Component Analysis (PCA) explores relationships of nutrient variables of Dairy and Egg Products based off data from the United States Department of Agriculture. By performing a PCA, we can simplify the dimensions of the data while still explaining a majority of the variance
Data source: U.S. Department of Agriculture, Agricultural Research Service. 2018. USDA Food and Nutrient Database for Dietary Studies 2015-2016.
title: PCA Analysis of Dairy Products

content:
Introduction: Snowshoe Hare Analysis of Age, Weight, and Sex This project contains an analysis of age, weight, and sex of captured Snowshoe hares (Lepus americanus) in Tanna Valley, Alaska. The study used the capture-recapture method from 1999-2002. Snowshoe hares experience population fluctuations of 8-11 years and are recognized as a keystone species in northern boreal forests.
Data Source: Kielland K., F. S. Chapin, R. W. Ruess. 2017. Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/03dce4856d79b91557d8e6ce2cbcdc14 Snowshoe Hare with White Fur During Winter. Photo Source: Sierra Club
   Data Cleaning for Analysis #Cleaning data to only keep SEX AGE WEIGHT and for age only keep Juvenile (j) and Adult (A), and for sex only keep (m) and (f) hare_new <- hare %>% select(sex, age, weight) %>% drop_na(sex) %>% drop_na(age) %>% drop_na(weight) %>% filter(sex=="m" | sex=="f") %>% filter(age=="a" | age=="j") %>% mutate(age = ifelse(age == "a", "Adult", "Juvenile")) %>% mutate(sex= ifelse(sex=="m","Male" ,"Female"))  Visualizing Hare Data jitter_hare <-ggplot(data=hare_new, aes(x=age, y=weight), textsize=1) + geom_jitter( aes(color = age, pch = age) ) + facet_wrap(~sex) + scale_y_continuous(expand = c(0,0), limits=c(0, 2000), breaks = seq(0,2000, 200)) + labs(y="Weight (grams) ", x="Age") + theme (panel.grid.major = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor = element_blank(), panel.background = element_blank(), axis.line = element_line(colour = "black"), plot.title = element_text(face="bold")) + ggtitle("Male and Female Hare Weight for Juveniles and Adults") + scale_color_manual(values = c("Adult" = "red", "Juvenile" = "black")) jitter_hare  Figure 1: Figure 1. Male and Female Hares: Age and Weight on Capture/Recapture from 1999-2002. Age is measured by juvenile and adult and weight is measured in grams.  The scatterplot is a nice way to visualize the weight of juvenile and adult snowshoe hares for both males and females in order to see which sex generally weighs more at both life stages.   Summary Statistics for Age, Sex, and Weight of Hares hare_counts <- hare_new %>% group_by(age) %>% count(sex) hare_mean <- hare_new %>% group_by(age, sex) %>% mutate(mean_weight = mean(weight)) %>% group_by(age, mean_weight) %>% count(sex) %>% select(age,sex,mean_weight,n) table_hare <- kable(hare_mean, caption ="Table 1. Age, Sex, and Mean Weight of Snowshoe Hares in Tanna Valley, Alaska from 1999-2002.", col.names = c("Age","Sex","Mean Weight","Sample Size")) %>% kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed", "responsive")) table_hare   Table 1: Table 1. Age, Sex, and Mean Weight of Snowshoe Hares in Tanna Valley, Alaska from 1999-2002.    Age  Sex  Mean Weight  Sample Size      Adult  Male  1499.1837  98    Adult  Female  1503.2308  65    Juvenile  Female  939.3939  66    Juvenile  Male  989.0385  52     From this table we can infer that as adults, female Snow Hares tend to weigh more than males, but as juveniles males tend to weigh more.
summary:
Introduction: Snowshoe Hare Analysis of Age, Weight, and Sex This project contains an analysis of age, weight, and sex of captured Snowshoe hares (Lepus americanus) in Tanna Valley, Alaska. The study used the capture-recapture method from 1999-2002. Snowshoe hares experience population fluctuations of 8-11 years and are recognized as a keystone species in northern boreal forests.
Data Source: Kielland K., F. S. Chapin, R. W. Ruess. 2017. Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present.
title: Snowshoe Hares

content:
Introduction: This project contains time series data for Steelhead Salmon passage across the Bonneville Dam in Oregon from 1939 - 2019. The analysis will include daily, seasonal, and yearly time series of salmon passage to visually and mathetmatically explore the fluctuations of the population over an 80 year time span.
Data source: Columbia River DART, Columbia Basin Research, University of Washington. (2019). Adult Passage Graphics & Text. Available from http://www.cbr.washington.edu/dart/query/adult_graph_text
Bonneville Dam, Oregon. Photo Source: DiscoverNW
  Data Analysis and Cleaning #clean data and create new columns for appropriate date formats needed new_salmon <- steel %>% clean_names() %>% mutate(newdate = paste(year, mm_dd, sep = "-")) %>% # get all 3 YDM mutate(parse_data = lubridate::parse_date_time(newdate, "ydm")) %>% mutate(final_date = yearmonth(parse_data)) %>% #coerce to tsibble `yearmonth` format mutate(value= as.numeric(value)) %>% # make value numeric drop_na(parse_data, value) %>% mutate(month = month(parse_data, label = TRUE)) # may want month later # Data Frame for totals of each month of each year year_month_salmon <- new_salmon %>% group_by(month,year) %>% summarize(total_salmon = sum(value)) # Data frame for total salmon each year year_salmon <- new_salmon %>% group_by(year) %>% summarize(year_total = sum(value))  Visualizing Daily Passage # plot for daily passage sthead_gg <- ggplot(data = new_salmon, aes(x = parse_data, y = value)) + geom_line() + theme_minimal() + labs(x= "Day and Year", y= "Total Steelhead Salmon Passage") + scale_y_continuous(expand = c(0,0), breaks = seq(0,40000, by = 5000), labels = scales::comma) sthead_gg  Figure 1: Figure 1. Daily Steelhead Salmon Passage at Bonneville Dam from 1939-2019.  Daily passage of steelhead from 1939 - 2019. This plot shows the variation of daily passage throughout 80 years, with the lowest ever at -75 individuals (death) on March 17th, 2005 and the highest daily at over 34,000 August 13th, 2009.
 Visualizing Seasonal Passage: Monthly Passage Per Year # season plot steel_season<- ggplot(data = year_month_salmon, aes(x= month, y = total_salmon, group= year)) + geom_line(aes(color= year))+ theme_minimal() + labs(x= "Month", y= "Total Steelhead Salmon Passage") + scale_y_continuous(expand = c(0,0), breaks = seq(0,450000, by = 50000), labels = scales::comma) + labs(color='Year') # Add a color scheme from paletteer steel_season + scale_color_paletteer_c("pals::ocean.curl") + labs(color = 'Year')  Figure 2: Figure 2. Seasonality plot of Steelhead Salmon passage at Bonneville Dam. Steelhead counts are totaled for each month and visualized throughout the years 1939-2019.  The season plot shows variation of monthly passages throughout the years. As seen in the plot, summer months of July, August, and September show the largest passage numbers through the years with the highest passage in July 2009 with over 350,000 salmon.
 Annual Steelhead Passage from 1939-2019 #Finalized Plot of Annual Steelhead ggplot(data = year_salmon, aes(x=year, y = year_total)) + geom_line(color = "bisque4") + theme_minimal() + labs(x= "Year", y= "Total Steelhead Salmon Passage") + scale_y_continuous(expand = c(0,0), breaks = seq(0,700000, by = 100000), labels = scales::comma)  Figure 3: Figure 3. Annual counts of Steelhead Salmon passage at Bonneville Dam from 1939 - 2019.  The Steelhead population has seen fluctuations in their passage numbers since 1939, with an all time high in 2001 at over 633,000, but in recent years has plummeted to 77,000 in 2019.
summary:
Introduction: This project contains time series data for Steelhead Salmon passage across the Bonneville Dam in Oregon from 1939 - 2019. The analysis will include daily, seasonal, and yearly time series of salmon passage to visually and mathetmatically explore the fluctuations of the population over an 80 year time span.
Data source: Columbia River DART, Columbia Basin Research, University of Washington. (2019). Adult Passage Graphics & Text. Available from http://www.
title: Steelhead Salmon Passage at Bonneville Dam
